item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

@OP: Even though you’ve said that you have refrained from developing this application because it’s “beyond your level”, you can always continue it as a mere learning experience, as ownagesbot clearly stated.

If you take it upon yourself to continue the project, here is an answer to this question:

[quote=“openice123, post:11, topic:292899”]Idk how to do anything else from now.
Like packets and making multiple players show up in the same map.[/quote]
Basically, upon a new client connection, after the login handshake(s) have been fulfilled, the server sends a packet similar to the one Lin posted. This packet contains all of the players that are within the current region (in other words, the players that are drawable) along with their characteristics. The client will have an array of “Player” objects, and will add each one according to the packet’s specifications. Then, in your drawing method, you will iterate through the player array and draw the players one-by-one according to their location on the screen and map.

Each time a player walks, the client will send the respective walk packet to the server, the server determines which players are within the region and sends the packet to them. The client will proceed to read the packet, identify the moved player and changed its location.

item.title: Multiplayer 2d Game?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“openice123, post:16, topic:292899”]I’m not working on this anymore because its beyond my level =[/quote]Shame, I think you’d learn a lot with perceiverance. Lin, RS sends the packetLen before the ID. It’s either 1 byte or 2 bytes, depending on the packet size. This does as Taharok mentioned, mark the end of the packet (well it doesn’t, it tells you how many bytes to read, but it as good as does the same thing). I think the way RS reads/writes packets may be a little complicated for openice123, for bandwidth issues, the packetLength is only 2 bytes when it HAS to be 2 bytes, determining this for both reading and writing is relatively simple, but perhaps confusing for openice123. I think he could/should do a similar protocol, but always send 2bytes for the length, this way hes guaranteed to have enough packetLength should he have quite a few players on, its highly unlikely he would suffer from the bandwidth/latency issues RS would have and its much simpler than formatting and determining the format of the packets like RS does.

(WORD (or java short))length // (byte)opcode // [optional]operands

If you decide to carry on with the project openice, add me on msn: razh54@gmail.com ill help you with anything you need.

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:14, topic:292899”]To be honest, the way I would go, is somewhat like RuneScape. You could also steal the Stream class from there, too. Basically, have a packet ID. Send the needed data from there. For example, you could do something like this to draw all the other people on the screen (Send it to each client).

The packet ID (Byte) Amount of players in the area (Byte) (Start looping for each player) The player gender (Byte) The distance (X) from you to the other player (Byte) The distance (Y) from you to the other player (Byte) The player face (Byte) (End loop)

If you wanted to make things easier, you could include the packet size after the packet ID, or you can just store the packet sizes in an array or list for later use.[/quote]

Only for static packets. For dynamic packets, you need to either store the size with it or have some sort of end-of-packet marker. This marker would also have to be on static packets, unless dynamic packets have special identifiers that differ from static packets. But that just complicates things in my opinion.

owangesbot I have no clue what you just said >.<
I’ve been doing private servers my whole time but I’ve never looked at the client to see how packets are sent and recived.

Could anyone care to explain how to make a packet system??

This is my streams class. It’s simple but works for sending and reciving data from the server.

[code]package tl;

import java.net.;
import java.io.;
import java.util.*;

public class Stream {

private DataOutputStream outDataStream;
private DataInputStream inDataStream;

public DataOutputStream getOutStream() {
	return outDataStream;
}

public DataInputStream getInStream() {
	return inDataStream;
}

public Stream(Socket connection) {
	try {
		OutputStream outStream = connection.getOutputStream();
		outDataStream = new DataOutputStream(outStream);

		InputStream inStream = connection.getInputStream();
		inDataStream = new DataInputStream(inStream);
	} catch(Exception e) {}
}

}[/code]

item.title: Multiplayer 2d Game?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

Yeah, you could do something like this:

length / opcode / operands

(example): 2 56 79

Where 2 is the length, 56 is the opcode (maybe the code for “Attack”) and 79 is an operand (maybe the players index i.e. 79).
Obviously, this small example has limitations, the fact that the length may not exceed 255 bytes, nor may the opcode be larger than the byte 255. If you think this will cover your needs then by all means go for it. Another approach could be the following:

length (2 bytes), opcode (2bytes), operands

This is pretty similar to before, only this time you are going to have 2 val for length/opcode this allows your length to be up to 65535. And opcodes up to 65535. (Providing you read into an unsigned short)
(Clearly each packet you send like this will be an additional 2 bytes, so it may effect performance).
As far as im aware, RSC atleast had no more than 255 opcodes and manipulated the raw data to see if the length of the next packet was 1 or 2 bytes. I guess they did this for optimization.

Anyway, gives you something to think about I guess.

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

By the sound of it, you are creating a new connection for each packet. Don’t do that. All you need is 1 Socket instance during the duration of the login.

And as for your alternating feet, that’s not too difficult. You need 2 sprites which have the alternating feet (assuming you already do), then you draw 1 for a few hundred milliseconds, then you draw the other. You just toggle between the two as you are walking, and it will display as a walking animation.
